messageBody:
## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-09-30T16:16:16Z
## Message ID: 20190930-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notification with ID 20190928-AL-002. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux is above 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-09-28T14:25Z. Flux is currently around 81,800 pfu. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2019-09-27T04:52Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-09-28T14:25:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes: 



NASA Community Coordinated Modeling Center/Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC, http://swrc.gsfc.nasa.gov ) Disclaimer

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 18, 2019 - September 24, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-09-25T20:56:39Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-09-18T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-09-24T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190925-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period. The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic period of 2019-09-24T15:00Z-18:00Z.  This slight geomagnetic disturbance was associated with the arrival of a coronal hole high stream combined with a small transient around 2019-09-24T10:51Z.  Solar wind speed reached values of ~500 km/s on 2019-09-25.  

STEREO A IMPACT and PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-09-21.  Solar wind speed reached values of >600 km/s on 2019-09-21.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-09-25T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-10-01T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are no significant active regions present on the solar disk.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be moderate for the upcoming weed due the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-09-28.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for September 04, 2019 - September 10, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-09-11T17:41:07Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-09-04T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-09-10T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190911-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=4 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2019-09-05T00:00Z-06:00Z, 2019-09-06T03:00Z-06:00Z and 2019-09-09T09:00Z-12:00Z.  The increase in geomagnetic activity at the beginning of the reporting period was associated with the lingering effects of the arrival of a strong coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2019-08-30.  The increase on 2019-09-09 was associated with a weaker coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2019-09-09. 

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES was elevated above the threshold of 10^5 pfu until 2019-09-08 due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above detected by ACE at L1 on 2019-08-30 (see notifications 20190904-AL-001 and 20190906-AL-001).  After 2019-09-08, they have remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the rest of the reporting period. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above. 

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-09-11T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-09-17T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are no significant active regions present on the solar surface.  Geomagnetic activity is also expected to be low for the upcoming week.

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-09-08T23:05:56Z
## Message ID: 20190908-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notifications with IDs 20190831-AL-004, 20190902-AL-001,  20190904-AL-001, and 20190906-AL-001. Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes continue in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-08-06T13:10Z and has continued to be near 70% - 80% of the threshold (10^5 pfu).

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2019-08-30T12:17Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-08-31T18:50:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for August 28, 2019 - September 03, 2019
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-09-04T21:09:42Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2019-08-28T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2019-09-03T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20190904-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There were no significant flares or CMEs.  

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=6 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2019-08-31T12:00Z-15:00Z and 2019-09-01T12:00Z-15:00Z.  This geomagnetic storm was caused by the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by ACE at L1 around 2019-08-30 (see notifications 20190831-AL-001, 20190831-AL-002, and 20190901-AL-001).  This strong coronal hole high speed stream disturbance lasted for several days and the solar wind speed reached values of ~800 km/s on 2019-09-01.  Currently, the solar wind speed is still elevated with values of around 560 km/s.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-08-31T18:50Z.  These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES were associated with the coronal hole high speed stream described above (see notifications 20190831-AL-003, 20190831-AL-004, 20190902-AL-001, 20190904-AL-001).  The fluxes are still currently elevated above the threshold with values around 160,000 pfu. 

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed 

Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
None Observed  

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2019-09-04T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2019-09-10T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low for the upcoming week.  There are only a few small active regions present on the solar surface.  Geomagnetic activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream around 2019-09-07.  Currently, the solar wind speed detected by ACE at L1 is still elevated due to the coronal hole high speed stream detected around 2019-08-30 and the > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt is elevated above the threshold of 10^5 pfu with values of around 160,000 pfu.  

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-09-04T13:39:52Z
## Message ID: 20190904-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

This is an update to the notification with ID 20190902-AL-001. Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. Energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt continue to be significantly elevated. GOES "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first exceeded 10^5 pfu starting at 2019-08-31T18:50Z and has continued to be above or near the threshold. It is currently around 121,000 pfu. 

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by a high speed stream starting at 2019-08-30T12:17Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-08-31T18:50:00-RBE-001.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Geomagnetic Storm
##
## Message Issue Date: 2019-09-01T16:04:08Z
## Message ID: 20190901-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Ongoing space weather storm in the Earth's magnetosphere. Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic period 2019-09-01T12:00Z to 2019-09-01T15:00Z. 

The storm is caused by the high speed stream starting at 2019-08-30T12:17Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO, polar and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's ring current and auroral regions can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2019-09-01T12:00:00-GST-001.
